OH MY GOD you guys, get with it. Eating disorders are caused by HISTAMINE. Serotonin and dopamine weirdness may happen, but histamine is literally the cause of eating disorders. Histamine makes you not hungry. It also makes you very self-critical. It causes obsessiveness (it literally causes OCD as well). People who are perfectionist, overachievers, "highly sensitive children," and many autistic people have VERY slightly elevated histamine chronically. People who have eating disorders have a moderate chronic histamine problem. Many, many foods trigger the release of a teeny amount of histamine and other inflammatory markers, but in some people, MORE histamine is released in response to every single thing that triggers a histamine release (which is actually a great number of things throughout a day in someone's life; eating, changes in temp and humidity, sexual arousal, circadian rhythms, etc.)
Antihistamines literally cure eating disorders. Do NOT take an antihistamine without talking to your doctor first if you are already on any meds as there can be interactions. But I promise you, histamine causes eating disorders, and antihistamines solve eating disorders.
The defining feature of anorexia should not be whether you want to lose weight, whether you think you are fat, etc, but whether you actually succeed in a long-term starvation diet. The only way that people are able to achieve a long-term starvation diet is when there is a physiological reason why starvation is PREFERABLE to eating. And a constant overdose of inflammatory markers is the most common reason why starvation is BETTER than eating. I want so badly to help everyone struggling with eating disorders, because I know it is hell. But it's not even a psychological disorder at all; doctors are just willfully ignorant about the effects of histamine as a neurotransmitter!

I had a problem with binge eating. I ended up gaining 70lbs over my healthy weight, and it caused a lot of health issues (joint pain, IBS, cystic acne, bloating to the point of pain, irregular periods, and depression). I’ve been able to figure out my life and help myself stop the binging, and have lost 50lbs. I already feel so much better. Less joint pain, better self image, my skin is clearing up, I don’t feel bloated anymore, and my period is regular again.
If you’re struggling with Binge Eating, please seek help. Just because BE doesn’t kill you quickly, it still makes you miserable and causes health problems. Please take care of yourself, you’re not alone, you are worth it.

~ I unfortunately have had Anorexia for almost 2 years now and before the weight-loss I had low self esteem and I thought I didn't look good enough. But now 2 years later, I feel very confident in my body, I wear whatever I want instead of wearing clothes and colors that won't stand out as to not be noticed. I now wear colors other than black and I actually want to be noticed. When the disorder first started I counted calories, but now I don't, I eat when I'm hungry (which isn't often :/ ) I don't see a fat girl in the mirror either like how others say they do...I see a girl who can take over the world. Before I didn't understand why my bf thought I was attractive and I used to feel ashamed for him to be seen with me...now I'm so proud of myself and I don't feel out of place. I get compliments all the time, and get stared a lot by both men & women. Also I have set myself a limit to how low I can go so I can pull back up, I look amazing just how I look now and I want to stay this way (In no way do I look like a skeleton, I look more like a model) . These realizations made me wonder if I really had/have Anorexia because I hear stories of it being hell and I am waiting to see that? Idk, everyone is different but I feel alone in this. (Basically my disorder has given me a huge confidence boost but I think it'll be short lived) Sorry for the long read, just wanted to share my story. I've been watching a lot of ED videos (mostly anorexia) and I'm starting to think certain subcultures and fads are right-down dangerous. Modelling and athletic environments, where being thin is highly prized and sought after, counting calories all the time. Gym culture that's about becoming fit/toned/muscular, but it's an artificial way to be physically active, with a focus on the exercise itself, rather than doing physical work, let's say, outdoors on a farm and the exercise and fitness coming along as a secondary effect. I'm not even going to say anything about the bodybuilding and steroids side of things. Fad diets that eliminate whole food groups, obsessing about eating "healthy" when really the obsession is a lot more dangerous than any unhealthy food you're likely to eat in a day.


I'm inclined to reject out of hand any push someone might give me towards preoccupation with my physical appearance. I refuse to accept it as a concern to be on my mind, I refuse the thin standards society pushes on people (especially women) as ideal, since they are actually not, I trust my own aesthetic sense a lot better. And I refuse to count calories, ever. Since I know myself to have an obsessive personality, I'm at higher risk from an obsessive eating disorder I might develop than from anything I might eat. I've already engaged in some behaviors that, looking back now, I recognize as dangerous, at 18 when I did lose a significant amount of weight in a relatively short time. It was never at the clinical level, but it shows my mind does tend to go in that direction.

Just to note, fasting is not a form of self punishment. True fasting is done dusk till dawn. Not days long. That is not sustainable and is actually unhealthy. It’s not fasting; it gives the whole practice that is actually for faith or health a dark image.
There are many people struggling out there and I’ll admit I had an eating disorder when I was eighteen after my fiancé left me. I didn’t have the stomach to look at food nevermind force myself to eat it. But my issues with myself and food sprung from a traumatic situation even earlier.
If anyone is reading this, please do get help. It’s not easy. It’s not fun and it sure isn’t glamorous. But it is worth it. The process is long and laborious. But there is such relief when you can finally receive the help you need and you don’t want to hurt yourself anymore.

Please nourish your bodies. It does everything it can to keep you alive. It’s on the same team as you. But a car can’t run on empty fuel. It’s about balance & moderation NOT restriction. I know because the step from “this is just a diet I just want to look good and restricting myself/binging/etc makes me feel in control” to having an eating disorder is way too easy. And once you have an eating disorder it’s hard to get out. You are BEAUTIFUL. If you feel like you NEED to change yourself physically to be beautiful, that’s a sign that something isn’t right mentally. Because you are already beautiful. To FEEL beautiful, work on your mental health. Get rid of toxic people. Take on healthy/creative hobbies that you enjoy. Feed yourself nutritious foods. And yummy foods that make you happy. Work out not to look good, but to feel good. Because it’s good for you. And your body will become stronger. And you will become stronger mentally. Don’t listen to the media. You are beautiful. From the inside out. Stop recognizing beauty in everything except yourself. And treat yourself with the love you deserve. God loves you. And He doesn’t make mistakes.

I heard a proposed reason why the system that anorexia nervosa activates even exists. The idea is that early humans were deprived of food when the environments they were in were depleted, so when you find yourself starving, your body prepares for a long journey to a new region. Part of this response is amping up norepinephrine, cortisol, and glucagon to liberate energy and fuel you on your journey -- resting metabolic rate actually goes up for a week or so before going down if you start fasting. Another part is suppressing hunger so you aren't distracted by tiny food sources along the way. A third is increasing your urge to exercise so that you're willing to expend the effort of walking to somewhere where there's more food.
So essentially, this hypothesis says that in anorexia, the "I'm out of food, so I'd better go find a new region with more" response somehow wakes up when it isn't needed and doesn't get the signal to go back to sleep, just like how metabolic syndrome is an inappropriate activation of the mechanism that prepares bears to hibernate and allowed early humans to gorge on seasonal fruit.

One of the reasons for binge/stress eating is because stress and/or anxiety cause the reptilian brain to go into survival mode which would make it so you eat as much as you can in order to store energy in case of an emergency where you might go for a long period of time without being able to eat. in this day and age we have convenience at our finger tips which means we wouldn't move as much as our ancestors in most cases. Which is why the energy reserves do not decrease or stay the same. The fat is just unused emergency energy. if you binge and/ or stress eat I suggest taking time off from what is stressing you out or giving you anxiety, do what calms you, GET SLEEP, exercise daily, and keep a journal of things you like about yourself/ are generally grateful for. (I know it's easier said than done)♥️

I have BDD & I can tell you exactly what it comes from and or why... As a overweight child I was bullied and that considerably lowered my self worth and confidence, to avoid mental abuse I completely altered my identity & I became hard, unforgiving & cruel ( I became the bully). Although I was somewhat inelegant, mildly funny & popular I was still overweight as a teen. As many people know teen years are the beginning years of forming and understanding of relationships with the opposite sex, but I was not attractive... I received nothing more than friendships from female's and I was placed into the category of "brotherly" figure or more commonly known as " Friend Zoned"... Being 240 and never having a girlfriend my junior year I had enough... I changed my diet, but I also became anorexic and sometimes I purged after meals, the weight dropped drastically. By the time I reached my senior graduation I had lost close to 60 pounds, but realized how my lifestyle was affecting my body (Crones, ulcerative colitis, brittle hair & bad skin) So I changed again. I exercised, ate healthy, supplements and vitamin' s for nearly 6 years now. At a healthy weight of 155 and considerable muscle tone & yet I still look in the mirror and see the same fat teenager... BDD is caused by years of bullying and lack of attention from the opposite sex. So in conclusion to all the teens that have had the attention span to read to this point... Go out there and date a chubby boy or girl, they are so much more than you believe them to be. They'll try harder, love more and be so much more loyal than your average "F Boy, or Girl".

I always suspected that I had Body Dysmorphic Disorder when I was younger, but wasn't formally diagnosed until I was an adult.  Ever since I was a small child (6 or 7 years old), I would spend hours in the mirror and obsessively pinch at my fat and other perceived imperfections. I would always compare my body to my friends', wishing I could look like them. I don't think that there has ever been a time that I have not looked at my body as a whole and been completely happy with myself. I have since received CBT, and although I still get stuck in those harmful thoughts, it doesn't rule my life, and I have a much healthier body image. For anyone dealing with this disorder, I would recommend going to therapy. It changed my life!

I felt marginally okay with the info until he got to around 6 minutes bringing up it mainly affecting upper class caucasian females and how our current environment idealizes thinnness. While that is true that the current environment does do that, that isn't to say other environments would not trigger an eating disorder, simply in a different way. Culture/ environment is show to shape how a mental illness may be expressed, but outside of culture bound illness, do not "cause" it per say. That is for instance, people with AN now in days often have this idea of wanting to be thin to be beautiful or whatever and phobic of gaining weight. In previous times, anorexia nervosa was called anorexia mirabilis, in which the fear of eating was associated with fear of being unpious in ones attempt to "deny the flesh" and so on. There are also studied in which AN occurs at the same percentage in societies where larger body types are desired. EDs also occur in countries such as Asia, but manifest differently at times, though are getting more similar to what we know due to Western influence. The current trend seems to be less around thinness at times and more on this idea of being "healthy" which then gets skewed. EDs also hit more around puberty for females due to hormonal changes. Prior to puberty, EDs occur in males and females at about the same rate. I can't recall what it is, but males basically have a protective factor that lessens the likelihood of an ED developing.
Which lead me to my last point of eating disorders basically being anxiety disorders. The whole "control" low self worth thing may be a component in sense for some, however the basic underlying pattern is experiencing and/or feeling something (anxiety, anger, frustration, etc.) believing it is in congruent to how one thinks things "should" be then trying to control or reassure oneself in some way, acting based on that fear/ desire to change that and make that feeling go away. It then just makes a giant cycle of constantly just acting on fear for short term relief, often to the detriment of ones long term health.
That being said this is a "crash course" so I wouldn't necessarily expect this all to be in there, but do wish the whole thing about self esteem and such wouldn't be put as a scape goat. In general it would be better to teach children [and teenagers and adults] about learning to handle uncertainty and feelings, while still doing healthy things that align with their goals and values.

When the compulsive thoughts take over you and you do them over and over and over, it’s all you can think about—everything else just disappears. thank you Crash Course. this was a great video to watch. i learned more about what self doubt can turn into. I have to say i was a bulimic for 7 years. starting when i was 17. it was because i wanted to be thiner. it was because my mother encouraged me to purge and use laxatives. it was because ever since i was little even the school doctor told me i was fat. but it did, in deed, turn into an addction in time. after my folks divorced i started binging and purging more heavily. i switched to vomiting. vomiting itself, doesn't just cause digestive issues. it also causes hormonal issues in time and more. besides being a little fat, i was and still am anemic. besides being a little fat, i was hypoglycemic, despite binging and eating a lot of snacks and sugars. it is just as a drug addiction, and i am not exactly sure how i manged to get over it. Good news, i did. it's been 3 years in which vomiting or using laxatives has never crossed my mind. my body finally receives a normal flow of nutrients. the bad part is that being used to that abnormal way of eating.( 6-10 meals a day that i puked them all and left... maybe a third of them in my guts. ) i rapidly gained weight. became obese. good part is that all the anxiety of calculating how much should i eat, when and where and how can i dispose of the over-binge. and hiding it. there were days when i would puke stomach acid. and there were days when i puked freshly chewed bread that would stop in my throat and make it hard to breathe. there were days were my eyes and skin around eyes was bloodshot. there were days where my throat hurt so much i couldn't even swallow water. There were days were i was simply euphoric from all that excessive vomiting that i would entertain myself with how water tasted sweet in my mouth due to stomach acid. there were days when i'd just eat something just for the purpose of vomiting, because vomiting cured my headaches or gave me a sense of calmness. i didn't seek professional help. i still don't know how i managed to convince myself to stop. but i am happy i did. i no longer feel that dizzying anxiety and urge to empty my stomach because it feels unnaturally uncomfortable to have a full stomach after eating. These days i dread i might trick myself to start going back to those days, despite being given diuretic medication, i feel the urge to skip it ever now and then, in fear of not getting caught up in the bulimia trap. being obese is causing me physical pain. it's not about the image of perfection anymore. (i still don't know why i had that obsession or how i lost it). one last thing, apparently getting my body used to the certain endorphines that vomiting induces in the bloodstream, the absence of them has also caused a hormonal imbalance and my body no longer has a good hormone production, i am suffering from  policystic ovaries, metrorragie and oligomenorrhea that comes with. being also obese puts me at high risk of diabetes, heart disease and many more. never in my life have a studied the safety of diets and have seeked professional help as i did now.  but it's good. i am not anxious, i am calm. i am in no rush. i am aware this hasn't happened over night and it won't get better over night either. i am determined to succeed. and ever more determined to never slip back in that disorder. looking back at it, it is a very impairing disorder. even bulimia can cause dehydration and fatigue from loosing a lot of liquids. liquids with mineral ions. being drowsy drunk-like is not helpful for staying awake and focused, or for making critical rational decisions.

You guys should cover ARFID! Avoidant-Restrictive Food Intake Disorder is a less touched upon but still dangerous and problematic disorder. It's most common in children, especially paired with other issues such as dissociation and depression in children. It's characterized by an extremely restrictive diet consisting usually of foods high in carbohydrates, sweet/mild in taste, and often excluding entire food groups like meats vegetables etc. other symptoms are high sensitivity to taste, smell, and texture, and panic anxiety related to eating foods the child usually does not eat, and a lack of hunger when subjected to stressors or triggers. When the disorder goes unrecognized (often brushed off as pickiness) it can progress into adulthood, getting increasingly difficult to treat. The largest problem encountered by ARFID sufferers is a lack of nutrients and routine eating, as appetite can suddenly drop for weeks at a time, making it hard to eat at all. This renders the person fatigued, often iron deficient, thin and malnourished, and excluded in social situations because of their difficult diet, which leads to more stress and in turn more starving. Please, please shed more light on this disorder. As a sufferer, ARFID is just as real and just as painful to live with as other more common eating disorders, yet it goes unknown and forgotten. Treatment is hard to get, too. Please help out your fellow ARFID sufferers, all the "picky eaters". Thank you.

Eating disorders can be a lifetime condition. I've had elderly patients (70s, 80s, 90s), all women, who have symptoms of unhealthy relationship with food. Preface: I'm going to ask a couple questions about diagnosis and attitude that I realize, in sensitive issues like this, may come across as dismissiveness or insensitivity, but I just want to clarify up front that I have absolutely no doubts about the legitimacy, power, and danger of BDDs.

My first question is about the way these issues are diagnosed. What is the line between a BDD and someone who is driven to achieve a healthier or more fit body? In my mind, the difference is clear, but a friend of mine had an experience with her therapist which makes me feel that my view does not match that of general psychology. Basically, I have a friend with a history of anxiety and depression that she has been working on for years. Recently, while she was talking to a therapist she started seeing a couple months before, and said therapist suggested that she may have a BDD. Here's the problem. She does take her fitness and weight very seriously, but she works toward her goals by balancing her diet and her exercise properly, rather than starving herself or purging. Fitness is something she can control and achieve with fairly rapid results.

Her issue, in my eyes and her's (we have some similar struggles and are very open with each other about them), is that she's not someone who fails well. When she fails, even if only in her eyes, that is one of her strongest triggers for episodes of depression. So, when she looks in the mirror and sees a body that doesn't meet her desires (or at least where she desires to be at a certain point in the fitness process), she has a high susceptibility to becoming depressed. The therapist heard this and immediately jumped to BDD, but I feel like she's missing the crucial difference between the phrases, "I'm worthless because I look like this (BDD)," and, "I look like this because I'm worthless (her)." Obviously, neither of these is a healthy outlook, but the former sees appearance as the cause one's shortcomings while the latter sees it as a result. Am I wrong to see a difference here?

Secondly, I'm concerned about the knee jerk reaction people seem to have when it comes to responding to someone's issues with body image, namely, the urge to immediately jump in with praise to counter the self-deprecating nature of the issue. I don't have a BDD, but I do have anxiety issues which can manifest themselves in some fairly severe self-deprecating thoughts. When someone responds to something horrible I've said about myself with a contradictory nicety, my first thought isn't, "thank you, I really needed to hear that," it's, "bull**." When I'm in a depressed place and you're nice to me, I just flat out don't believe you. Worse, if these niceties are offered by a stranger (see the numerous comments in this thread), I go from brushing the comment off to, "who the ** are you to tell me what I am!? What you're telling me could be said to literally anyone, and you can't possibly mean it because you couldn't possibly know!" (Remember in the earlier video when he mentioned that male anxiety and depression often manifests itself as anger...?) What I'm saying is, you do not have the time to out nice the mean going on in my head.

Anyway, I know my feelings aren't universal, but people should be aware that throwing platitudes around might make you feel better, but they may not be received as you hoped, and they are, objectively pretty meaningless. Another issue with automatic platitudes is that they're often offered to counter a perfectly healthy desire for self-improvement. Early in the video, Hank quoted a survey about the percentage of children who felt that they wish they weighed less, the point of which seeming to be to point out how early body image issues can become an issue. However, my mind immediately jumped to the fact that our country (I'm American) is at an all time high with childhood obesity, and surely there is an overlap in this Venn diagram of children who wish they weighed less because they SHOULD. What good does it do to tell an obese child not to think about their weight because they're already perfect, no matter what? This doesn't mean that we should be saying, "duh, fatty. Fix your disgusting self." That would obviously be extremely detrimental, and I'm sure hearing similar sentiments was a catalyst for many people who eventually developed a BDD.

A proper response to a child who expresses a desire to lose weight might be something along the lines of, "well, why don't we work together to learn some healthy habits and get more fit?" Notice how the wording of this reply replaces "lose weight" with "get more fit" but doesn't do it blatantly, which may come across as being dismissive of their original goal. "Healthy habits" helps to highlight what the actual goal of the endeavor should be, but none of these is the most important word. The most important word is "we." In using it, you are making a promise to that child that they will not be alone in their efforts (SO DON'T LET THEM BE). As you work through the process, learning healthy eating habits, creating an exercise routine, you can create a kind of mantra that "we are getting fit in order to be healthy." Hopefully, it will eventually sink in and replace, "I am losing weight to be attractive." Just like you can't replace a poor physique with a healthy one by doing one curl, you can't replace a poor mentality with a healthy one by teaching one lesson. Additionally, occasionally remind them that their appearance is in no way connected to their worth as a human being. Don't do it so much that they feel like you're beating them over the head with it, but just enough that it will hopefully stick in the back of their mind. There's a lot of "hopefully" in this process, I know, but that's because everyone is different. That's why it's so important that you stick with them. If you see anything that starts to seem like an unhealthy obsession, you will be right there to offer support.

At this point, I should mention that this response is meant for people who have the kind of relationship with the child that will make such a promise possible. If you do not have such a relationship, either bring up this conversation to someone who does or butt out because it's not your business. "I bet there are a lot of people in your life who would help you meet your goals," is a good phrase to learn.

If you're suffering from eating/body disorders, GO AND SEEK HELP! I know it is hard to talk about it, especially with your family. But please just talk to someone! It can be anyone, a friend, teacher, neighbor, as long as you talk to someone. I've suffered from anorexia in the past, and I know as well as you that starving and over-training won't remove the stress and anxiety long term, it will only make it worse.
The first step towards getting your life together, and getting rid of the anxiety once for all, is to talk to someone. It's hard to get rid of the disorder without the support of others. I was stubborn at first, I thought it was my private life, that no one had the right to intervene with. Now afterwords I see that I was afraid that people would judge me, see me as weak. Therefor I kept it to myself. My school teacher even had to force me to sit down with her and talk it through. She wasn't angry at me, didn't look down on me, she cared for me and wanted to help me. You'll find that a lot of people really care for you and are willing to help, even though it dosen't feel that way right now.
The second step, is to recognize the disorder. As I said, I was stubborn. It took weeks before I accepted the truth, and months before I could see what anorexia had done to me. Even now a year afterwords I'm still not fully recovered. I'm still bench eating to some extent, and I find it really, really hard to talk about it. But I feel better, a lot better. Most of my anxiety is gone, and I've found myself a lot more self confident.
So once more, please seek help.

Oh God, I remember my teenage years. I was the textbook young, white, female, restrictive anorexic case. At 6'1'' I weighed 112 lbs at my lowest.  I weighed myself like 9 times on a typical day, and on really bad ones dozens of times. It was common for me to spend up to two hours of my day looking at the mirror. I monitored calorie content tyrannically, subcategorizing bananas, for example, into 'small', medium', and 'large' and knowing the exact amount for each. I collected that kind of information in spreadsheets, made weight plots, and memorized hundreds of food labels exactly. I lived to watch the scale slide down and was so proud of myself when I went without food for a long time. Then when I absolutely couldn't take it anymore and had to eat again (as, of course, I eventually did) I felt enormous guilt. Needless to say, It was a ridiculous phase of my life. Interestingly, I correctly did not think I was fatter than others. I thought I wasn't skinny enough, which is different. Anything other than a wispy, skeletal, figure was unacceptable by my consuming personal standard and "fat".

I used to have problems with binge eating, periods of bulimic behavior and using excessive exercise and starving or strictly controlled dieting to cope with body dysmorphia and depression from the time I was 11- 15. for an entire year when I was 13, I worked out vigorously for up to 3 hours a day(running till I puked, elliptical training for an hour and a half, weight lifting and insanity) and ate between 500-1000 calories a day. I was still considered overweight by every bi chart, but ate only spinach, lettuce, carrots, grapefruit, water and sometimes 4 Oz of baked chicken or turkey or an eggwhite. Everytime i noticed that I wasnt losing weight, id get super depressed and go into binge eating, purging and self harm. At 16 I developed healthier eating and exercise habits, but I still had a lot of problems with depression and body dysmorphia. now I'm 17 and I've been getting so much better because I became vegitarian and started biking. Having a positive outlook on the food I consume and doing activities that I enjoy instead of viewing food as an enemy and exercise as a control has helped me recover and view myself in a positive light. I still get triggered every time I see a scale, and a month ago when I visited the doctor, the nurse told me my weight in passing and I was extremely triggered and distressed, but they didn't realize it had an effect on me. In the car I had a panic attack and had extreme depression for two weeks, but honestly, that I still better than I used to be. my parents don't believe I should seek therapy, but I'm going to try as soon as I move out. Being vegitarian and doing lighter exercise that is fun and social is what keeps me the healthiest mentally and physically.

Sometimes this sort of disordered eating can happen without even wanting to be thin. By the beginning of 4th grade, I weighed only about 50 lbs, as opposed to my previous average weight of 70 lbs. I always felt nauseous around food, and would feel like throwing up just by smelling it. I often consider the trigger for this problem when I watched a documentary on the bubonic plague on the first day of that summer. After that, I threw up, and became convinced that whatever I did, the disease would follow me. There'd be days I would lay in bed with a giant hole in my stomach, feeling intense hunger pains, but ignoring it because I knew I wouldn't eat anything. My definition of a "good dream" was one where I ate without feeling sick. We started ordering pizza a lot, because that was the only thing I could get down. I was pale and anemic, and didn't have enough energy to do the things I enjoyed doing. Thankfully, I got better, but to this day I can't find anything on what was going on. Help?

OSFED has 5 subtypes: Atypical Anorexia,  binge eating disorder, purging disorder, night eating syndrome and Bulimia* (at a lower frequency) people with osfed can struggle with all of these subtypes in phases. and that's why is has a high mortality rate.  many people with osfed experience a cycle and its different for everyone.  for example.  a person goes from heavily restricting --> Binging and purging --> binge eating --> restricting with purging disorder --> restricting.   and then over again as a cycle thats why is super damaging.

A common feature (and trigger) of BED actually does include fasting. Various studies have concluded that feelings of deprivation via fasting/ purposely skipping a meal/a few meals often does trigger a binge eating episode. It is widely hypothesized that ghrelin (appetite stimulant) counteracts the effects of leptin (appetite suppressant) when released into the blood stream during periods of starvation, which then may lead the subject to binge.
Here are two significant sources that discuss the above findings and other cognitive functions underlying BED: 1) Hellström, P., Geliebter, A., Näslund, E., Schmidt, P., Yahav, E., Hashim, S., & Yeomans, M. (2007). Peripheral and Central Signals in the Control of Eating in Normal, Obese and Binge-Eating Human Subjects. BJN British Journal of Nutrition.; and 2) Wolff, G., Crosby, R., Roberts, J., & Wittrock, D. (2000). Differences in daily stress, mood, coping, and eating behavior in binge eating and nonbinge eating college women.

You did a MAJOR disservice in this episode by not mentioning OSFED (otherwise specified feeding and eating disorder, formerly EDNOS.) More people suffer from OSFED than any of the other eating disorders (in fact, more than anorexia and bulimia combined,) and it's the most deadly of all the eating disorders (5.2% mortality rate versus 4% for anorexia and 3.9% for bulimia,) primarily because it is so rarely recognized in time due to lack of awareness. OSFED is the catch all classification that accounts for all eating disordered people who do not fit the strict diagnostic criteria of anorexia or bulimia. Binge eating disorder is actually a subtype of OSFED, but there are several others. One example would be the Atypical Anorexia subtype, which is anyone who has all the symptoms of anorexia but have not yet dropped into an unhealthy BMI. This is an egregious omission on the part of CrashCourse.

Also, some of your points seem to be outdated. For instance, having a BMI below 15 (classified as "extremely underweight") is no longer a diagnostic criteria for anorexia, only not maintaining a healthy weight (BMI of 18 or under.) 

These probably don't seem like big issues for anyone who has not suffered from an eating disorder, but this kind of misinformation is why so many eating disordered people do not get treatment and end up dying of their disease.

I was "Lauren", but it happened when I was around 20.
My family moved about 6 times in one year at 15, and lost some weight, I recovered after we stabilized there for a few years.  Age 19 to 20, I hadn't the funds to just move out into a permanent address of my own when I heard we were moving  ......again. I started to diet. This started a bad spiral.
 One of my parents died during this move....and I was still dieting.....and we then moved three times after that.
 
Needless to say, it all went out of control. I lost even more weight, the hair started falling out and I got zits galore, with a protruding spine, flat bottom, flat chest, it just doesn't scream "sexy". I was between 100 and 105 pounds. Yes, I am big boned.
 I wasn't diagnosed with anorexia by a physician, but looking back, I definitely had it.
After the third move at 22,  I got off the merry go round of moving, I left got my own apartment with a friend. I was in control, now. I regained an appetite, got up to 125. I  never went "back home",,,,and yes, they did move twice after that, and I sat in my apartment, and smiled in my one bedroom scantily furnished apartment. .

Things that didn't help:
Moving out of state into new schools as a teen.  It's HARD for teens.
 Being told constantly I "look good" by some family and friends, even after getting down to 110 pounds. This encouraged me to lose even more weight.
Teen and glamour magazines. STAY AWAY!!  JUST STAY AWAY!!
Fashions catered to thin people in the 80's, so it seemed.  If you were a size 5, you got to wear well made  jeans with the cool appliques that came with the cool belt.  If you were heavier, it was polyester pants with a stretch band. I can't say it's the same today.

This video is pretty good, but I wish Hank talked about EDNOS (Eating Disorder Not Otherwise Specified), the most common type of eating disorder. Because EDNOS is less acknowledged than Anorexia, Bulimia, or BED, many people suffering from EDNOS feel unworthy of treatment or are even brushed aside as "not sick enough" by healthcare professionals when they seek help. In reality, EDNOS is just as dangerous and deadly as Anorexia and Bulimia. Everyone's body reacts differently to various disordered behaviors. My starvation and overexercise affected my organs far more than they affected my appearance. I was diagnosed with EDNOS and hospitalized on the same day because my heart rate was under 30 beats per minute, and I was never technically underweight.

It's not something you want, it makes you look horrible and lose so many important things. I recovered but I'm now suffering again. I remember when this vid first came out... My family was already thinking I looked too skinny and had me weighed. When I saw this vid when it was first uploaded I realized how I wasn't even close to how the video described anorexia except for a couple minor things. Now a month later I realize how wrong I was. My goal before all of this was to get the abs that you seem models have... I started excersising then eventually increasing it to 1 hour and 30 min of ab excerises. Sometimes even 2 hours. Then I started eating healthy because I heard 80% in the food and 20% in the excersising from a credited source to help get abs. Eventually over time this healthy eating ended up in the end getting rid of any type of milk, butter out of my diet, no desserts, etc. When I started cutting things out such as butter and milk I had stopped excersising due to school starting. My meals were basically egg white, 12 grain toast, straberries. Lunch was a turkey sandwich (lettuce, 3 pieces of thin turkey, and some tomatoes) on 12 grain bread and a protein drink (it only have 1/2 cup of milk). Then for dinner, I wouldn't eat anything fried, etc. I would  eat shrimp with a salad, turkey salad, or anything along those lines. By that point, my mom didn't realize I cut out the milk, or butter. So, she asked to weigh me one day and I lost 7 pounds in under a month. Now, this wasn't really intentional all I wanted was to be healthy and have abs... I was originally 87 and 1/2, then I weighed 80... I thought it was insane. I didn't look super dead or anything in my eyes. I tried to get back to normal by eating healthy but be less rigid, so I would eat peanut butter and jelly etc. Obviously that wasn't working because I even dropped to 78. I saw this video and saw all the signs of crackling skin, always being cold, etc. I saw online how anorexics judged their carts in food stores compared to others and other signs. All of them were true about me except losing hair. I didn't thing much of it. Now, my story is nothing in comparison to the girl in the story with being 5' 7" and only being 82 pounds. I'm 5' 3" and currently 82. I have been eating more in the past month trying to get back to a normal weight. I don't look at the calories on boxes anymore, I try to look at them as if they are just a number. I think I'm doing good so far, hopefully I won't relapse or anything. Sorry if my grammar was bad or something, it's just that this is a way for me to say something about it without me caring who reads it... I think I'm on the right path now and I've had cookies and ice cream for probably the first time in like 6 months within this past month. It's a good feeling to be going in the right path :)

As someone who has been diagnosed with IBS (irritated bowels syndrome), many people tend to assume I suffer an eating disorder; however, the two disorders are not the same. I would like to point out that you do not have to be underweight to be anorexic. Although often it is a defining characteristic it is not always that way. A-typical anorexia is when a person has a healthy or even overweight or obese BMI, but enacts in behaviors such as: restricting, fasting, purging, laxative abuse, compulsive exercising and many more. People who have a-typical anorexia and are not at a low weight or even if they are overweight are in just as much medical danger as an anorexic who is underweight. Everyone’s bodies no matter the size react in the same ways to starvation. Eating disorders only come in one size, miserable. If you are overweight or a “normal” weight and you struggle with ED behaviors you deserve help. You do not have to be “thin enough” in order to deserve help and treatment. I am an a-typicle anorexic and I have almost died several times from this disease even though I have always had an overweight BMI. Eating disorders do not discriminate.

Ok, so I notice a lot of downright ignorance by the general population on this topic. Here is the great secret in gaining and losing weight:

1. If you eat more than your energy expenditure, you gain fat and muscle (muscle only if you excercise), if you eat less you lose fat and muscle (muscle only if you are on starving mode). Simple as that; unless you have a terrible parasite or genetic disorder, which I bet isn't your case (stop lying to yourself).
2. How do I know if I'm over- or undereating? Weight yourself every week, measure your body fat percentage (it's easier than you think; use a body fat caliper) and keep a log. I also highly recommend counting your calories if you have doubts or specific goals (high-protein diet, for example), but after some time you create habits and know your drill.
3. There's not such a thing as "naturally chubby" or "naturally skinny", you are just not eating in the correct amounts. Breaking bad habits is very hard, I know, but the faster you accept your excesses and lacks are all your fault (unless you are a child and have terrible and/or ignorant parents), the faster you can start getting to do something about it.
4. Don't have fear of failure. When you fail you learn, and learning is always good.

"I eat so much and never gain weight." - you are overestimating what you eat. Maybe you eat 8 apples a day (that's a lot), but that's still equivalent to half a bar of chocolate in calorie terms.

"I keep dieting and excersicing and can't lose weight."  - you are overestimating the amount of excercise and/or underestimating your caloric intake. Eating those three cookies after your very healthy salad still counts. Eated more? Then excercise more.

"I have a high/low metabolism" - you don't.

Actually Hank, EDNOS (or atypical eating disorder I think in the latest DSM) is the largest category of eating disorders, especially as it encompasses those who present with AN behaviours but without the weight criteria (and previously without the amenhorrea) as well as those with b/p tendencies but for whom the frequency of behaviours occurs less than the DSM standard. EDNOS is also as lethal, if not more lethal, than AN. It is also horribly overlooked and usually dismissed with a "but you don't look thin enough to have an eating disorder" despite behaviours.

As a diagnosed Binge Eating Disorder individual, I really have come to believe that a big chunk of what drives us with ED's into active manifestations has to do with our thoughts. We have very self destructive thought processes, with a very black and white mentality. Combine that with either an unsupportive family environment or consistently negative school experiences on a social level (or worse have both), and eventually these thoughts drive our perceptions and twist our view of ourselves and the world in a very unhealthy manner. Looking back, now that I understand how my unhealthy mind works, I can trace the progression from when my ED began to form via my thoughts to the moment it switched on and became Active on a physical level.

If you are suffering, you are not alone. For most of us, admitting we have an ED is the hardest part of recovery. Find support groups, seek out people who also suffer but are in treatment. Hell, if you need someone you can even message me. We can only get through this when we truly feel that someone understands the F'd up stuff happening in our head. Knowledge and learning and understanding what we are dealing with is our greatest weapon to combat it now and in the future.

Also a lot of negative and misinformed comments in the dooblydoo here. I suggest if people still don't understand then research it, watch videos by people with eating disorders or those in recovery. If you have questions about history speak to a historian.

Dear Crash Course,
Is it weird that sometimes I almost want to have an eating disorder? I don't want to hurt myself or anything, but it's almost as though I want to know what it feels like to have that problem.

A glossed over though somewhat disturbing factor here is the common misconception of the two disorders Anorexia and Bulimia. I have heard medical doctors, nurses, and the general population define it as simply "Anorexia is restricting, Bulimia is purging."  And usually specifically vomiting, not even the laxative or other methods.  It might seem like a minor thing, but I've heard it used in circumstances that are troubling, someone clearly anorexic, but  because of this misconception (that is slowly but surely leaving, though not fast enough) they see an anorexia diagnosis as a "lesser" diagnosis and carry on with the thought that "at least I'm not Bluimic."  

The MOST disturbing thing left out though, is a societal shift in the completely wrong, horrifying direction of "pro-ana" groups.  People that consider anorexia a lifestyle choice and SUPPORT it, at risk to life scares me to no end.  The idea of someone giving tips to young people as to how to purge is physically sickening to me. It's a complicated, horrifying rabbit hole to wander down.  I'm all for the end of social stigma with mental disorders ESPECIALLY these ones, but there is a line and to me this is clearly over it.

I was a fat, short kid and my mom always wanted me to lose weight. One day I looked in the mirror and realized just how fat I was. I started losing weight the healthy way when I was 12 years old. Eating large portions but eating healthy food, and exercising. I would diet/exercise every summer and lose 10 pounds exactly. I was so proud of my body. I stopped dieting/exercising for a while and gained around 7 pounds but didn't really care. Freshmen year of high school, I started dieting during the school year, replacing meals with salads and doing more exercise during the week, I hated it so much. I started running out of fear of gaining weight again.

Despite all this, I had great friends and I loved, and still love my life. I'm very creative and a straight A student who loves sports and acting, and everything in between.

Halfway through junior year, a switch flipped inside of me. I was terrified of gaining weight. I thought if I pushed myself hard enough, I could finally be skinny. I exercised constantly, people told me I looked good but soon people stopped commenting. My self esteem plummeted even though I was one of the skinniest girls in school. I stopped caring about everything, I stopped writing, I stopped reading. The only thing I looked forward to was finally being able to slip into sleep, which was hard since my stomach was always cramping and growling.

My point is, when you have an eating disorder, you don't realize it. People always told me I was one of the best and happiest people they'd ever met and I still starved myself to near death. You think you're finally in control of your life, that people will finally like you. The hunger takes over your brain and makes you depressed, paranoid, and suicidal.

I would like to point out that BMI is a very very bad number to use for individuals. It is meant to be used as a general value for looking at populations.
A bulimic person for instance may be normal weight according to BMI but have dangerously low muscle mass. If you work out on the other hand and have built up some muscle mass you can have dangerously low fat mass and still be "normal weight".

I'm very disappointed that EDNOS/OSFED wasn't discussed for even a few seconds. Those of us with it already often feel as if it's not real because we're "not sick enough" to be anorexic or bulimic, and considering that it is the most common ED, I'm very surprised it wasn't discussed.

You don't have to be underweight or throwing up to have an ED.  In fact, the DSM V removed weight criteria for diagnosis for AN for a reason: requiring someone to be 15% below an acceptable BMI causes a lot of issues for those who are abusing the hell out of their bodies but haven't dropped below the diagnostic threshold.

Even with that change, though, some people don't meet all of the diagnostic criteria for AN or BN (or meet diagnostic criteria for both), and so are slapped with the catch-all EDNOS/OSFED label.  It is still serious and is still dangerous and I wish you'd taken even ten seconds to discuss it when it's far more common than muscle dysmorphia.

My sister developed what seems to be an eating disorder from an old medication she regularly took which had a side-effect of causing the user to become hungrier faster than normal. Even though she doesn't take the medication anymore, she still feels that she needs to eat excessively, or she'll starve. This isn't likely to also be related to or seem to cause distress, such as low self-esteem, to her, so it wouldn't be Binge Eating Disorder, by definition, but it definitely isn't making her lose or maintain BMI, so it wouldn't be Anorexia or Bulimia Nervosa. What would it be?

There have also been recent suggestions by some psychologists that a new eating disorder be added to the list:
They call it "Orthorexia," and define it as an obsessive refusal to eat foods that the sufferer believes are "impure" or "unhealthy" accompanied by an obsessive need to check that their food is "pure."  For instance, not eating anything at a family dinner because they haven't personally checked that every ingredient is non-gmo, locally grown, and organic.  Liking those things is totally fine, but when you can't eat for fear your food has been "contaminated"...that's when it becomes ED territory.

The one thing this video was lacking was  EDNOS (eating disorder-not otherwise specified). It's one of those things that you never hear about, but only hearing the version of anorexia that requires one to be 15% underweight can make people suffering from EDNOS feel that they are "not sick enough" to recover (believe me, I've been there). I suffered from EDNOS with anorexic tendencies (basically with the same tendencies as an anorexic person and the same effects aside from being "sufficiently" underweight) and BDD for almost 2 years (still not entirely recovered)  and I know one of the major factors that kept me from admitting that something was wrong was that I didn't fit the anorexic mold. There are so many misconceptions about restrictive eating disorders (particularly the weight range associated with them) and it would be very helpful if you could maybe explain a bit about EDNOS in a future video.

There is a link between EDs and OCD, as well as BDD and OCD.  It is not uncommon for EDs to 'evolve' into OCD, as people may recover from an ED, but the underlying issues have not really been addressed.  Addictions and OCD can all be manifestations.  There is also a strong tendency towards these problems if you have PTSD or/and Borderline Personality Disorder/BPD traits.  I hope that you will do videos on BPD and other personality disorders.  These mental health videos are excellent.

Hank, I really enjoy crash course Psychology- they are all themes I'm already familiar with, but it's really satisfying to hear them explained so well and so impartially. However, I really do feel the need to point out that Anorexia Nervosa can occur at ANY weight- if the person continues to restrict food for a long period of time it can lead to drastic, and often mortal, weight loss, but the disorder itself can occur at any weight. So can Bulimia. And so can Binge Eating Disorder. A lot of people don't seek help because they do not feel they are 'sick enough'. That no one would take an overweight anorexic seriously, even though they've been subsisting on little food and exercising excessively for months. That no one would care about a binge eater that's underweight, even though they've been struggling with binging for years. It's important to acknowledge that these disorders can occur to anyone regardless of gender, sex, weight, body mass index, of general outward appearance, so that the 'not sick enough' mentality is eradicated both from the minds of healthcare professionals and people who are too dubious and afraid to seek help. It has to start with the proper education, which is why I'm saddened that this episode pushed the low body mass index of Anorexia as a definitive and imperative part of the disorder. If anyone out there reading this finds themselves restricting or purging their food intake, or engaging in disordered eating or dieting (you don't want to eat certain foods because you feel they're bad and fattening, you exercise until you feel faint, you only eat certain amounts of foods or foods you feel are 'safe', you are obsessed with your weight, etc etc etc) SEEK HELP as soon as possible, no matter your weight. The sooner you stop these thoughts in their tracks, the faster, smoother and easier the road to recovery will be.

I just wanted to mention that not everyone with anorexia nervosa is actively trying to lose weight. I struggled with it in middle school but it was more a subconscious thing. I lost my appetite due to depression and ate very little to the point where my stomach shrank so I didn't even have enough room to eat much without feeling bloated even if I tried. I never actively tried to lose weight it just happened. I think people have that misconception sometimes that everyone with an eating disorder is trying to lose massive amounts of weight which in the most common cases they are but there are some that don't fit that mold. There's also the fact that, for me, it was really hard to gain weight because I have a high metabolism so I burn fat easily. That mixed with anorexia is a disaster. I don't struggle with eating at all now, for anyone that cares. Because I wasn't trying to lose weight it was easier for me to overcome it but I still had to be hospitalized and force fed with an NG tube because it was so difficult for me to get out of it at first. I was hospitalized for half a year and only struggled with it for about a year and a half. To put into perspective I was 13 when I started losing weight, I'm 17 now but only within the past few months have I really started to gain weight.I was at a steady 5 pounds below the recommended weight for myself for two years after being released from the hospital.
